member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectSquish
member.summary: Reduce the element to its top-left corner.
member.remarks: Works safely with most Block Elements, except tables.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectBase
member.summary: Base class for all Scriptaculous effects

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.IScriptaculousEffect
member.summary: Denotes a ScriptaculousEffect

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.IScriptaculousEffect.Sync
member.summary: Sets whether the effect should render new frames automatically (which it does by default). Set this to true in usage of EffectParallel or other scenarios where you want to control the rendering of each frame yourself

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.IScriptaculousEffect.ScriptaculousQueue
member.summary: Sets queuing options.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.IScriptaculousEffect.AfterUpdate
member.summary: Client Function that will be invoked on each frame update of the Effect.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.IScriptaculousEffect.AfterFinish
member.summary: Client Function that will be invoked after the effect is complete. Quite useful for restoring and keeping in sync the program

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Constructor. Specify Duration and Delay

member.summary: Includes the script files.

member.summary: Populates the properties.

member.summary: Set the lifetime of the Parallel execution

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectBase.Delay
member.summary: Set the delay before the Parallel execution commence.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectBase.Transition
member.summary: Sets a function that modifies the current point of the animation, which is between 0 and 1. Following transitions are supplied:

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectScale
member.summary: EffectScale will scale the element and optionally it's children to a given percentange. For example 120 denotes to scale something from 100% to 120% - a 20% increase from it's previous size.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase
member.summary: Base class for all scriptaculous effects which includes scaling

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase.ScaleMode
member.summary: Either ‘box’ (default, scales the visible area of the element) or ‘contents’ (scales the complete element, that is parts normally only visible byscrolling are taken into account). You can also precisely control the size the element will become by assigning the originalHeight and originalWidth variables to scaleMode. Example: scaleMode: { originalHeight: 400, originalWidth: 200 }

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase.ScaleX
member.summary: Sets whether the element should be scaled horizontally, defaults to true.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase.ScaleY
member.summary: Sets whether the element should be scaled vertically, defaults to true.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase.ScaleContent
member.summary: Sets whether content scaling should be enabled, defaults to true.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase.ScaleFromCenter
member.summary: If true, scale the element in a way that the center of the element stays on the same position on the screen, defaults to false.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.ScriptaculousEffectWithScaleBase.ScaleFrom
member.summary: Sets the starting percentage for scaling, defaults to 100.0.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectSlideUp
member.summary: This effect simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements scroll up and down accordingly
member.remarks:
Include a second div element, wrapping the contents of the outer div. Your element must look like this:
contents
The target element should not have padding set, otherwise you’ll see the effect “bouncing”. Because of a _bug in Internet Explorer 6 (overflow not correctly hidden), an additional wrapper div is needed if you want to use these effects on absolutely positioned elements (wrapper is the absolutely positioned element, x has position:relative set):
contents
Works only on block elements. In Internet Explorer 6.0 there’s a problem where floated block level elements don’t animate. If you add a position: relative to the element it all works though.The opposite of Effect.SlideDown is Effect.SlideUp.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight
member.summary: This effect flashes a color as the background of an element. It is mostly used to draw attention to a part of the page that has been updated via JavaScript or AJAX, when the update would not otherwise be obvious.
member.remarks: If the restorecolor option is not given, Effect.Highlight tries to find out the current background color of the element, which will only work reliably across browsers if the color is given with a CSS rgb triplet, like rgb(0, 255, 0). Also be aware that applying an effect (without setting a restorecolor), to an element that already has an highlight effect in progress, will cause the restorecolor to be set to the elements background-color at the time of the new effect, and not the original background-color. For example, click the example below 4-5 times in quick succession, and the paragraph will stay yellow as opposed to the original white.

member.name: M:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight.PopulateProperties(Gaia.WebWidgets.RegisterEffect)
member.summary: Populates the properties.

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight.StartColor
member.summary: Sets the color of first frame of the highlight. Defaults to ”#ffff99” (a light yellow).

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight.EndColor
member.summary: Sets the color of the last frame of the highlight. This is best set to the background color of the highlighted element. Defaults to ”#ffffff” (white).

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight.RestoreColor
member.summary: Sets the background-color of the element after the highlight has finished. Defaults to the current background-color of the highlighted element (see Note).

member.name: P:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectHighlight.KeepBackgroundImage
member.summary: Unless this is set to true, any background image on the element will not be preserved.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectGrow
member.summary: “Grows” an element into a specific direction
member.remarks: Works safely with most Block Elements, except tables. You can define different durations for several div elements, and place them in a row in order to make them appear one after another.

member.summary: This effect simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements stay in place.
member.remarks: Works safely with most Block Elements, except table rows, table bodies and table heads. The opposite of Effect.BlindUp is Effect.BlindDown.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectAppear
member.summary: Make an element appear. If the element was previously set to display:none inside the style attribute of the element, the effect will automatically show the element. This means that display must be set within the style attribute of an object, and not in the CSS in the head of the document or a linked file. In other words, this Effect will not work if display:none is set within style tag or linked CSS file. Alternatively, display:none can be set using a document.getElementById script even if no style is set in the style attribute.
member.remarks:
Works safely with most HTML elements, except table rows, table bodies and table heads. On Microsoft Internet Explorer, this effect may display a bold/ghosting artifact on elements that don’t have a defined background. It’s unclear if this is a feature or a _bug. Microsoft Internet Explorer can only set opacity on elements that have a ‘layout’. To let an element have a layout, you must set some CSS positional properties, like width or height.
See Giving Elements Layout. The opposite of Effect.Appear is Effect.Fade.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectFade
member.summary: Makes an element fade away and takes it out of the document flow when the effect is complete by setting the CSS display property to none. Opposite of Effect.Appear.
member.remarks: Works safely with most HTML elements, except table rows, table bodies and table heads. On Microsoft Internet Explorer, this effect may display a bold/ghosting artifact on elements that don’t have a defined background. It’s unclear if this is a feature or a _bug_. Microsoft Internet Explorer can only set opacity on elements that have a ‘layout’. To let an element have a layout, you must set some CSS positional properties, like width or height. See Giving Elements Layout.

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectBlindDown
member.summary: This effect simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements stay in place.
member.remarks:
Works safely with most Block Elements, except table rows, table bodies and table heads. Also, if you would like the block hidden when someone first lands on your page, you must use the display: none property within the style attribute of the div/block tag, and not in the CSS class for the div. Example:
Blind content

member.name: T:Gaia.WebWidgets.Effects.EffectSlideDown
member.summary: This effect simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements scroll up and down accordingly
member.remarks:
Include a second div element, wrapping the contents of the outer div. Your element must look like this:
contents
The target element should not have padding set, otherwise you’ll see the effect “bouncing”. Because of a _bug in Internet Explorer 6 (overflow not correctly hidden), an additional wrapper div is needed if you want to use these effects on absolutely positioned elements (wrapper is the absolutely positioned element, x has position:relative set):
contents
Works only on block elements. In Internet Explorer 6.0 there’s a problem where floated block level elements don’t animate. If you add a position: relative to the element it all works though.The opposite of Effect.SlideDown is Effect.SlideUp.
